BIOGRAPHY

I am a research scientist in the AI team at the Cardiovascular Center of Seoul National University Bundang Hospital, working in close collaboration with cardiologist Prof. Kang. I earned my M.S. from the Advanced Application for Intelligence Systems Laboratory, where I studied deep learning theory and explored novel learning approaches under the guidance of Professor Yung-kyun Noh. My thesis (link) proposes novel learning methods for handling censored data in survival analysis, along with a new objective function designed to directly optimize classification metrics in particle physics. I am fundamentally interested in the theoretical challenges of machine learning for large-scale data. Currently, I focus on developing practical AI solutions for clinical applications.

PROJECTS

1. Video Frame Interpolation for Coronary Angiograms

  • Abstract
    Coronary angiography (CAG) is the standard imaging modality for evaluating coronary artery disease; however, its cine X-ray acquisition protocol results in substantial radiation exposure, with reported mean values of 326.9‚ÄØ¬±‚ÄØ107.5‚ÄØmGy for air kerma and 2341.1‚ÄØ¬±‚ÄØ849.9‚ÄØŒºGy¬∑m¬≤ for dose-area product. Lowering the frame rate from the conventional 15 frames per second (fps) to 7.5 or 3.8 fps has been shown to effectively reduce radiation dose‚Äîby 30% for operators and 19% for patients at 7.5 fps‚Äîyet low frame rates often degrade visual realism, limiting their adoption in clinical practice. To address this limitation, we propose a deep learning‚Äìbased video frame interpolation approach that enhances low-fps CAG videos to 15 fps equivalents. The developed algorithm was quantitatively and qualitatively validated, demonstrating high fidelity in reconstructing intermediate frames. In this study, we evaluate the clinical utility of the interpolated videos through a blinded assessment by cardiologists with varying levels of experience. Participants reviewed both interpolated and real 15 fps CAG videos to assess image quality across multiple evaluation criteria.

2. Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease Risk Prediction in Koreans using Kolmogorov-Arnold Network

  • Abstract
      Duration: Jun 2024 - Our paper is currently under peer review.
      Role: First author, Proposed the idea and independently implemented all preprocessing and models with guidance from medical experts.

    Long-term prediction of individual atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk remains a critical challenge in cardiology. Among models trained and validated using health screening data, the multi-layer perceptron (MLP) has generally demonstrated strong or state-of-the-art performance. In addition to machine learning approaches, several statistical models‚Äîsuch as PREVENT and PCE‚Äîhave been applied in clinical practice. These models estimate ASCVD risk using simple equations that take a few health screening variables as input. In this study, we aim to develop a more accurate, and clinically applicable risk prediction model by leveraging the Kolmogorov‚ÄìArnold Network (KAN), which offers greater interpretability than MLP, to generate a simple and interpretable equation for ASCVD risk estimation.
    \[ f^{\text{KAN}}(\mathbf{x}) = -a g_1(\mathrm{x}_{1}) + b g_2(\mathrm{x_{2}}) + c. \] The detailed mathematical formulations can be found in our forthcoming publication.

  • Contributions
    1. To the best of our knowledge, the largest real-world data analysis on a Korean population.
    2. The first application of KAN to the 10-year ASCVD risk prediction task.
    3. A simple, interpretable risk prediction formula designed for clinical use, similar to conventional equation-based models.

  • Challenges
    1. Resource: The security policies of the National Health Insurance Service (NHIS) of South Korea are highly strict. Then, data access was only permitted within a designated analysis center provided by the institution, where computational resources were extremely limited.
    2. Imbalance: ASCVD events were highly imbalanced at a ratio of approximately 21:1, with a very low proportion of positive cases.
    3. Evaluate: After pruning the trained network, a simplified formula was extracted and its performance was evaluated.
  • Solutions
    1. Resource: Minimized hyperparameter tuning time by estimating appropriate network complexity through Exploratory Data Analysis. Modified parts of the official KAN code due to version mismatches in the required packages and analysis environment.
    2. Imbalance: Applied weighted loss for training and used both AUROC and AUPRC for evaluation.
    3. Evaluate: Developed a pipeline to convert the symbolic formula extracted from the network into a Python function using SymPy package and evaluated its output on the test dataset.

3. Data Reconstruction Method for Learning to Censored Survival Data

  • Abstract
      Duration: Jul 2022 - Jul 2023
      Role: Project Lead, First author, I independently conducted all theoretical development, modeling, and experiments.

    Classical machine learning struggles with right-censored data due to incomplete target values. However, since censored data indicates survival beyond a known threshold, it can still inform comparisons with uncensored data‚Äîenabling use in evaluating the concordance index (c-index), a metric for survival time ordering. This study proposes a novel method that reconstructs data into pairs, aligning with the c-index structure, and represents them as matrices for classification. Our approach directly optimizes the c-index by intuitively leveraging censored data. Evaluations on three real-world datasets show competitive performance with established survival analysis methods such as partial likelihood, rank-based approaches, and the Wasserstein metric, with no significant performance differences (t-test, p-value > 0.05). Additionally, we observe improved performance as the proportion of censored data in training increases.

  • Contributions
    1. A novel matrix-based data reconstruction method to directly optimize the concordance index (c-index) using right-censored survival data.
    2. Reformulation of the survival analysis task from a regression to a classification problem, enabling effective use of incomplete target labels.
    3. Empirical demonstration of competitive performance across three real-world survival datasets (SUPPORT2, AIDS3, COLON DEATH), showing no statistically significant difference from state-of-the-art methods (t-test, p > 0.05).
    4. Verification of the utility of censored data through experiments that progressively increase the ratio of censored observations in the training set.

  • Challenges
    1. Right-censored data do not provide complete survival times, limiting their use in standard supervised learning.
    2. The original c-index is a discrete and non-differentiable metric, complicating gradient-based optimization.
    3. Reconstructing all acceptable pairs into matrix form leads to exponential growth in training data size, which can become a bottleneck with larger datasets.
  • Solutions
    1. Instead of discarding censored data, they were included by forming ‚Äúacceptable pairs‚Äù based on their minimum known survival threshold and using them in the c-index. Introduced a rule-based mechanism for generating training matrices from acceptable data pairs, including handling equal survival times.
    2. Derived a surrogate, differentiable version of the matrix c-index and proposed a new loss function that enables gradient descent training in neural networks.
    3. Leveraged large mini-batch sizes and GPU-based optimization to handle exponential data growth from pairwise reconstruction.

4. Assistive AI in Endoscopy

  • Abstract
      Duration: Apr 2022 - Jul 2023
      Role: Team member, The following functionalities and models were designed and implemented independently based on requirements provided by the team leader.

    Early detection and accurate characterization of polyps during colonoscopy or gastroscopy are essential for preventing gastrointestinal cancers, particularly colorectal cancer. Manual detection is highly dependent on the endoscopist‚Äôs experience and is subject to variability and oversight. Automated polyp detection systems can assist clinicians by improving lesion recognition rates, minimizing missed polyps, and standardizing outcomes. Furthermore, differentiating adenomatous from non-adenomatous polyps in real time enables informed clinical decisions, potentially reducing unnecessary biopsies and optimizing patient management. The integration of AI-based tools in endoscopy thus holds promise for enhancing diagnostic accuracy, efficiency, and long-term cancer prevention. To this end, I have carried out several research and development projects focused on creating an AI assistant for endoscopic procedures:
  • Generated synthetic colonoscopy image data using denoising diffusion models
    1. Generated augmented training datasets to support further studies of real-time polyp detectors.
    2. Trained and validated a denoising diffusion model tailored for colonoscopy image synthesis.
    3. Overcame hardware limitations to produce 64√ó64 resolution images and passed expert review by gastroenterologists.
  • Automated cecum detection
    1. Developed deep learning model for real-time cecum recognition to automate withdrawal time measurement.
    2. I defined a binary classification task to distinguish the cecum and ileocecal valve from the background in endoscopic frames.
    3. Utilized Vision Transformer (ViT) with Grad-CAM-based heatmap visualization for interpretability.
    4. Applied TensorRT optimization for real-time deployment.
    5. Released in demo units for clinical testing
  • Designed a monocular camera-based system for estimating polyp size in real time
    1. Developed polyp size estimation algorithm based on monocular endoscope images.
    2. Used known dimensions of biopsy forceps as reference objects for scale estimation.
    3. Designed bounding box correction algorithms to adjust polyp dimensions relative to reference objects.
    4. -
  • Developed a model to distinguish whether the endoscope is inside the body (in vivo) or outside the body (ex vivo)
    1. Created an algorithm to distinguish whether the endoscope is inside (in vivo) or outside (ex vivo) the body during endoscopy.
    2. Analyzed RGB and HSV values from endoscopic video streams to define effective threshold ranges.
    3. Implemented real-time classification logic based on color value thresholds.
    4. Released in demo units for clinical testing

5. Efficient Learning for Identifying Additional b-jets in the \( t \bar{t} b \bar{b} \) Process

  • Abstract
      Duration: Sep 2020 - Mar 2022
      Role: Key Contributor, I proposed the initial surrogate loss function \(L_1\) and the ranking-based loss function \(L_2\), and designed and conducted a synthetic data experiment to validate the effectiveness of the concept.

    The \(ttHbb\) process is an essential channel to reveal the Higgs properties but has an irreducible background from the \(ttbb\) process, which produces a top quark pair in association with a b quark pair. Therefore, understanding the \(ttbb\) process is crucial for improving the sensitivity of a search for the \(ttHbb\) process. To this end, when measuring the differential cross-section of the \(ttbb\) process, we need to distinguish the b-jets originated from top quark decays, and additional b-jets originated from gluon splitting. Since there are no simple identification rules, we adopt deep learning methods to learn from data to identify the additional b-jets from the \(ttbb\) events. By exploiting the special structure of the \(ttbb\) event data, we propose several loss functions that can be minimized to directly increase matching efficiency, the accuracy of identifying additional b-jets.
  • Contributions
    1. The limitations of the conventional binary classification approach for this task were clearly demonstrated both theoretically and experimentally.
    2. The identification problem was redefined by leveraging the unique structure of the \(t\bar{t}b\bar{b}\) process.
    3. Four surrogate (\(L_1-L_4\)) loss functions were proposed to directly optimize the evaluation metric, matching efficiency, and their superiority over existing methods was demonstrated through experiments.

  • Challenges
    1. Required to build foundational understanding of particle physics to address domain-specific problems.
    2. Needed to demonstrate that the existing binary classification approach was suboptimal for this task.
    3. Task-specific evaluation metric was non-differentiable, making direct optimization difficult.
    4. Needed to explain the distinctive properties of each proposed model.
  • Solutions
    1. Collaborated closely with a particle physics research group for domain knowledge and validation.
    2. Designed synthetic datasets resembling real particle data structure to theoretically and empirically prove the weakness of baseline methods.
    3. Analyzed the metric‚Äôs properties and derived a differentiable approximation as a surrogate loss for training.
    4. Created multiple data subsets based on task characteristics to evaluate and interpret model performance effectively.
